awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program and SBE's Documenting Endangered Languages program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Patience Epps at the University of Texas at Austin, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist studying how young children develop the ability to direct others' attention. While  the development of joint attention behaviors in U.S. children learning English is well understood, joint attention development in other cultures has gone almost unstudied. This gap leaves a key question unanswered: do children learn joint attention behaviors from adults, or are they innate? Adult joint attention behaviors, such as pointing and use of demonstrative words like "this" and "that", vary massively across cultures. If children's joint attention behaviors are learned, they should reflect this diversity. If they are innate, they should be uniform, even between children living in radically different cultures. 

The researchers will test these competing theoretical predictions through a comprehensive study of language and joint attention development in children who belong to the Ticuna ethnic group. The research team will combine observational and experimental methods, including (1) collecting daylong audio recordings of children, made with wearable devices; (2) gathering video recordings of task-oriented communication between children and of child-caregiver interaction; and (3) conducting eye-tracking experiments. Through analyses of this data, the project will transform knowledge of language development in indigenous communities both directly, by producing documentation and analysis of children's acquisition of Ticuna, and at a disciplinary level, by creating new methods for integrating first language acquisition research into general language documentation projects. The researchers also anticipate broader impacts in education. In other NSF-funded research, U.S. language revitalization practitioners have identified an urgent need for studies of first language acquisition in indigenous settings. Results of this project may therefore inform the design and evaluation of programs which aim to create new first language speakers of Native American languages in the U.S.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Children have a strong drive to share attention with caregivers. Sharing attention with others allows us to label objects with names, coordinate our actions, and cooperate, creating the infrastructure for the rest of language and social interaction. For US and European children learning English, the development of attenion-sharing behaviors is well understood. But in other languages and cultures, they have gone almost unstudied, leaving it unclear which behaviors children learn from adults, and which are innate.

In this project, researchers studied the development of attention-managing behavior by young children who belong to the Ticuna people, an Indigenous Amazonian ethnic group. During research in a Ticuna community in Peru, the team recorded 45 children aged 1 to 4 years old interacting with their families in their homes, then analyzed how the children used language and gesture to manage others? attention.

One key research study analyzed how children learned attention-calling words equivalent to this/that and here/there in English. The team found that, because of children's drive to share attention, Ticuna children learned these words at extremely young ages, when they knew very few other words. For example, 12 of 14 Ticuna one-year-olds in the study produced this/that or here/there at least once. This is similar to findings about this/that and here/there in children learning English, Spanish, and Mandarin. Even though those languages have very different grammar from each other and from Ticuna, and are spoken in very different social settings, children learning each language produce these attention-calling words at nearly the same age. This suggests that the universal drive for joint attention has similar effects on language learning - especially on the very first words - across populations. No matter what language they speak, caregivers can expect that children will start using words like this/that and here/there at around 12-18 months old.

But though young children want to share attention with others, they don't understand others' perspectives very well. In another study, researchers compared when Ticuna children learned self-centered (egocentric) spatial expressions (equivalent to this near me) vs. interactive spatial expressions (equivalent to that near you). Children began using egocentric expressions first, and took almost two years longer to begin using interactive ones. They also used egocentric expressions more often than adults, with these words making up as many as 15% of all words they spoke. Child development scientists have long known that young children have trouble understanding what other people are thinking. This part of the research adds the finding that children also struggle with understanding how other people view objects in space. This means that parents, as well as others that care for young children, do not need to be concerned if children under 3 years old use interactive words like this/that, here/there, and me/you incorrectly. While adults think of these words as simple, their meanings are challenging for children to understand at young ages. Using these words incorrectly is normal for children, and they will usually grow out of mistakes on their own.
